conclusion: Line 'a' represents the U-I relationship of the silicon photocell under a certain light intensity.
Line 'b' represents the U-I relationship of a resistance R.
The intersection point of these two lines represents the operating point when they form a closed loop.
We need to find the internal resistance of the photocell at this operating point.
The intersection point occurs at I = 0.2 A and U = 2.5 V.
The internal resistance of a photocell can be calculated as r = -dU/dI.
To find the internal resistance, determine the slope of the U-I curve at the intersection point.
The internal resistance is defined as r = -dU/dI = -(ΔU/ΔI).
The open-circuit voltage (when I = 0) is U ≈ 3.6 V.
At the operating point, U = 2.5 V and I = 0.2 A.
The voltage drop due to internal resistance is ΔU = 3.6 V - 2.5 V = 1.1 V.
The internal resistance is r = ΔU/I = 1.1 V / 0.2 A = 5.5 Ω.
Verify by looking at the slope of the dashed line connecting the open-circuit point to the origin.
The dashed line has a slope from the origin (0,0) to (0.4, 0).
The slope of the dashed line is -5/0.4 = -12.5 V/A.
The photocell's actual U-I curve (line 'a') is not linear, so the internal resistance varies with the operating point.
At the operating point (0.2 A, 2.5 V), the internal resistance is approximately 5.5 Ω.
The internal resistance of the silicon photocell when formed into a closed loop at this light intensity is 5.5 Ω.
